Vapor-phase intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione over calcium hydroxyapatite catalyst Enggah Kurniawan Writing – original draft Data curation Takuro Yoshinari Data curation Visualization Yasuhiro Yamada Supervision Validation Satoshi Sato Conceptualization Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Yayoi, Inage Chiba 263-8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Yayoi, Inage, Chiba, 263–8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Vapor-phase production of 3-methylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (MCP) via intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione (HD) was performed over calcium hydroxyapatite (HAP) catalysts aged under various conditions. The aging temperature and time of the as-prepared apatite precipitate significantly affected the catalytic activity of the resulting HAP catalyst by influencing its residual carbonate and nitrate species and specific surface area. The HAP aged at a temperature between 50 and 200 ºC showed the highest catalytic activity with a high MCP selectivity of ca. 95%. However, serious deactivation was observed in an N2 carrier gas flow due to coke formation. The modification of the HAP catalyst with silver and the utilization of H2 as a carrier gas significantly reduced the coke formation and improved the catalytic stability during aldol condensation of HD to MCP. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Intramolecular aldol condensation 2,5-Hexanedione Calcium hydroxyapatite Aging process Deactivation control Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Reduction of the dependency on fossil fuels by utilizing a more sustainable and abundant carbon source is vital to tackle the environmental problems associated with the growth of energy and chemical demands. Catalytic transformation of biomass-derived compounds to various value-added chemicals is essential in achieving this goal since biomass utilization is a carbon-neutral process [1–3]. Among numerous biomass-derived compounds, 2,5-hexanedione (HD) has received great interest due to its application in polymers, solvents, pharmaceuticals, and fuels industries [4]. HD can be derived from sugar via hydrolysis of dimethylfuran (DMF) [5–9]. Aldol condensation has been considered as a key reaction in biomass valorization due to its promising route to various value-added chemicals [5]. The intramolecular aldol condensation of HD to 3-methylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (MCP) ( Scheme 1), in particular, is essential in producing chemicals used as gasoline additives and rocket fuels [6,7]. Hence, an efficient catalyst design that could selectively transform HD to MCP is considered to be economically valuable. Conventional homogeneous bases such as NaOH and KOH are often used in the HD-to-MCP transformation [8]. However, the homogeneous catalytic system suffers major drawbacks, such as difficulty in separating the target molecule and catalyst, being non-reusable, and often producing stoichiometric waste [10–12]. Thereby, a simply-prepared heterogeneous catalyst for aldol condensation of HD to MCP with high efficiency and selectivity is highly desired. For example, Nishimura et al. have recently established alumina/AlOOH catalysts for the liquid-phase flow aldol condensation of HD to MCP [9]. Our previous reports have shown that the acid-base properties of the catalyst were essential for the aldol condensation reaction [13–15]. Calcium hydroxyapatite (HAP, Ca10(OH)2(PO4)6) has interesting acid-base properties and has been reported to act as a catalyst and a catalyst support in numerous catalytic transformations. The nature of the acid-base site in the HAP catalyst could be tuned by changing the Ca/P ratio [16], type of metals [17], and preparation procedures [18]. This acid-base tunability allows the optimization of the HAP catalyst for an efficient catalytic transformation. For example, Larina and co-workers optimized the acid-base site in the HAP catalyst for Guerbet condensation of ethanol to butanol by partially replacing the Ca2+ with Mg2+ and Sr2+ [19]. Akagiri et al. tuned the acid-base properties of the HAP catalyst to convert 1,6-hexanediol to various C-6 compounds efficiently by changing the Ca/P ratio and sodium content [20]. Meanwhile, Kaneda and Mizukagi described the utilization of HAP as catalyst support for various organic reactions such as hydrogenation, oxidation, hydrogenolysis, and dehydrogenation [21]. The above-mentioned reports demonstrate the potential application of HAP catalyst for intramolecular HD-to-MCP aldol condensation. Furthermore, the HAP catalyst does not contain toxic and precious metals, adding more value to a green and sustainable catalytic transformation. In this paper, the ordinary HAP catalysts were used as heterogeneous catalysts for vapor-phase intramolecular HD-to-MCP aldol condensation. The effect of aging in the HAP preparation and some catalytic parameters were investigated to correctly understand the catalytic behavior of the HAP catalyst. In addition, catalyst deactivation controlled by using the Ag-H2 method was performed to improve the catalyst stability during the aldol condensation of HD. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The HAP catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation followed by aging at various temperatures. Typically, the desired amount of Ca(NO3)2 in 25% aqueous NH3 was mixed with (NH4)2HPO4 in 25% aqueous NH3 at a Ca/P ratio of 1.67 and a pH of 10.0. The mixture was transferred into a 100 cm3 container made of polytetrafluoroethylene (Teflon), and the container was placed in a pressure-resistant vessel. The vessel was then heated at various temperatures. After a prescribed aging time, the precipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed with distilled water three times, and dried at 110 °C for 15 h. The HAP sample was then calcined in air at 300 °C for 3 h. The resulting HAP catalyst was denoted as HAP-T-t, where T is the aging temperature (°C) and t is the aging time (h). An additional HAP sample was prepared in the 100 cm3 Teflon container with silica glass assuming the use of glass-made vessel. In the same manner as described above, the HAP precipitate was aged with several glass tubes, where the silica glass tubes (ca. 11.8 g) with the total silica surface area of ca. 110 cm2. After the aging with silica glass, 0.0833 g of silica was dissolved from the silica glass tube at 200 °C for 24 h, while 0.0073 g was dissolved at 80 °C for 24 h. The Ag-modified HAP catalyst was prepared using an aqueous solution of AgNO3 by the incipient wetness impregnation method. The AgNO3 solution of 20 cm3 was added onto 1.0 g of HAP in several batches, and the water was evaporated by illuminating the batches with a 350-W electric bulb so that the surface temperature of supports reached 70 °C. The evaporation process was repeated until all the solution with the Ag precursor was added. After the impregnation was completed, the solid was calcined at 300 °C for 3 h. The Ag-modified catalyst was then denoted as yAg-HAP-T-t, in which y is the weight percent of Ag. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was recorded on New D8ADVANCE (Bruker, Corp.) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) to identify the crystal phase of catalysts. The thermogravimetry (TG) analysis was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku Corp.) under the conditions: sample weight, ca. 10 mg; the rate of the temperature increase, 5 °C min−1; heating range, from the room temperature to 750 °C. The thermal decomposition (TD) profile with mass spectrometer (MS) was recorded on BELCATII with BELLMASS unit (Microtrac BEL Corp.) to identify the components of thermally produced gasses: a sample (50 mg) was heated from 100 to 800 °C in a He flow of 30 cm3 min−1 at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 after the sample had been heated in the He flow at 500 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 100 °C, where the preheating process was performed to remove pre-adsorbed gases. The produced gases were monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a quadrupole mass analyzer. The temperature-programmed desorption of adsorbed NH3 and CO2 (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD) was performed using BELCATII (Microtrac BEL Corp.) with a TCD detector to estimate the acid-base property of catalysts. Details in the procedure was described in the supporting information, as has been reported in the previous papers [22,23]. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The vapor-phase aldol condensation of HD was performed in a fixed-bed glass tube reactor. After the catalyst bed with a catalyst powder of 0.5 g had been heated in a carrier gas at a prescribed temperature for 1 h. A pure HD was fed through the reactor top at a liquid feed rate of 1.8 g h−1 and was vaporized in the flow reactor with a carrier gas flow of N2, N2 with 5%NH3, N2 with 5%CO2, or H2 at the flow rate of 1.8 dm3 h−1. The liquid effluents were recovered in a dry ice-acetone trap (−78 ºC) every hour for a time on stream (TOS) of 5 h. The effluents were analyzed by an FID-GC (GC-14A, Shimadzu Corp.) with a 30-m capillary column of InertCap1 (GL-Sciences Inc.). The carbon balance higher than 97% was achieved in the catalytic tests except the initial 1 h, and the degree of reproducibility was higher than 90%. The details of the procedure for the catalytic reaction were described in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of aging temperature of the HAP catalyst on its catalytic activity Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of HAP-T-24 calcined at 300 °C. After the aging for 24 h followed by calcination at 300 °C, the typical diffraction patterns of hydroxyapatite were clearly observed, which confirmed that HAP samples were successfully synthesized. Notably, higher aging temperature led to the formation of HAP catalyst with a better crystallinity. The effect of aging temperature was further investigated on the catalytic activity of the resulting HAP-T-24 catalyst, and the results are summarized in Table 1. The catalytic activity of the HAP-T-24 increased as the aging temperature increased up to 80 ºC (Entries 1–3), and further increment of the aging temperature was proven to decrease the catalytic activity of the HAP-T-24 (Entries 4–6). The time courses of Entries 1–6 are depicted in Fig. S1. It is apparent that the trend of the catalytic activity of the HAP-T-24 was in line with the specific surface area (S BET) of the catalyst. Thus, the aging temperature might affect the surface area of the resulting HAP catalyst, which consecutively affects its catalytic performance. 3.2 Effect of aging time of the HAP catalyst on its catalytic activity Table 2 reveals the effect of aging time on the catalytic activity of the HAP-50-t catalysts. Prolonging the aging time increased the specific surface area of the HAP-50-t catalyst and promoted the catalytic activity of the intramolecular aldol condensation (Entries 1–5). The aging time of 72 h was proven to give the highest catalytic activity; however, a long catalyst preparation might hinder the large-scale preparation of the catalyst. As a result, the aging time was limited to 24 h for catalyst preparation for further analysis. Notably, the HD conversion and MCP selectivity could also be promoted by a long aging of 168 h at 25 °C (Entry 6). Table 2 also shows that the HAP-50-t catalyst without aging had the lowest selectivity towards MCP, and a significant amount of dimethyl furan (DMF) was observed as the side product. The selectivity towards MCP gradually increased as the aging time was prolonged at 50 °C. Similarly, the HAP-25–24 catalyst only had an MCP selectivity of 83.9%, with a DMF selectivity of 12.4% (Table 1, Entry 1). Fig. 2 shows the TD-MS profiles of several HAP catalysts calcined at 300 °C. The HAP-25–0 sample had desorption of carbonate and nitrate species such as CO2 and NO with m/z = 44 and 30, respectively (Fig. 2A). The decomposition of nitrate residue did not produce NO2 species because the m/z = 46 peak was not observed in Fig. 2A. The HAP-80–24 catalyst had a small desorption peak of nitrate species with m/z = 30 (Fig. 2B), while the HAP-200–24 catalyst, which had the highest aging temperature, had neither desorption peaks of carbonate nor nitrate species (Fig. 2C). The TD analysis in Fig. S2 clearly indicated that a strong desorption peak of nitrate species around 700–800 °C was observed in the HAP-25–0 and HAP-25–24 catalysts. This peak disappeared when the aging was performed at 50 °C and above for 24 h (Fig. S2). Concurrently, the disappearance of carbonate and nitrate species was accompanied by substantial decrement of the DMF selectivity, thus promoting the MCP selectivity. Therefore, the formation of DMF from HD might have been driven by the presence of carbonate and nitrate species in the HAP catalyst and applying a higher aging temperature with prolonged aging time could remove the carbonate and nitrate species, which shifted the selectivity towards MCP. We have previously investigated preparation of ZrO2 with aging in basic solution in glass and non-glass vessels [24]. SiO2 dissolved at pH= 10 could be deposited on zirconium hydroxide during aging process. A similar silica contamination onto ZrO2 catalyst has also been reported recently by Shin et al. and the silica contamination was proven to improve the catalytic activity of the ZrO2 catalyst during alcohol dehydration [25]. Table 1 also demonstrates the catalytic condensation over another aged HAP sample (Entry 7), which was prepared in the Teflon container with several pieces of silica glass tubes. After the aging at 200 °C for 24 h, most of dissolved silica (0.0833 g) could be deposited on the precursor HAP (ca. 2 g) to produce 4 wt% silica-deposited HAP (SiO2-HAP) sample. As shown in Table 1, the S BET of SiO2-HAP-200–24 was 39 m2g−1, which was lower than that of the HAP-200–24 (44 m2g−1). We also conducted TPD measurement of SiO2-HAP-200–24 and the acid-base property was discussed later in Section 3.5. Fig. S3 shows the changes in the catalytic activity of HAP-200–24 prepared with and without the silica glass tubes during aging. HAP aged with SiO2 showed a higher DMF selectivity than HAP aged without SiO2 together with the decrement of the HD conversion (Table 1, Entry 7). This result significantly indicates that contamination of HAP is affected by aging process such as temperature, time, pH of the aging solution, and quality of vessel whether glass or Teflon. In addition, in aging of HAP precipitate with silica glass at 80 °C for 24 h, 0.0073 g of silica glass was dissolved to deposit 0.4 wt% silica on HAP. Although the silica loading was unconfirmed, the catalytic activity was not affected by the small amount of silica contamination (Data not shown). Concretely, aging at a temperature of 50 °C or higher for 24 h could remove contamination of carbonate and nitrate species, and non-SiO2 vessel would be preferable to avoid silica contamination. We summarize previous research on the preparation of HAP for numerous catalytic reactions (Table S1). Several works adopt aging at a room temperature [26–28]. Many papers disclosed no clear description on the quality of vessel of the aging equipment and the pH of the aging solution. The low aging temperature would induce the contamination of carbonate and nitrate. In fact, carbonated HAP has been prepared by aging in the presence of bicarbonate ions at 50 °C for 2 h [29]. It is worth noting that contamination of nitrate, carbonate, and silica might affect the acid-base property of the resulted HAP and their catalytic activity for both conversion and product selectivity. 3.3 Effect of calcination of the HAP catalyst on its catalytic activity Although HAP-80-24 is more active than HAP-200-24 (Table 1), we described majorly HAP-200-24 catalyst afterward because the preparative work was the latest finding in this paper. Fig. 3 shows the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity of the HAP-200-24 catalyst at 350 °C while Fig. S4 displays changes in the HD conversion with TOS. The average HD conversion decreased as the calcination temperature increased; meanwhile, the average selectivity to MCP remained high and was not affected by calcination temperature. It has been previously reported that increasing calcination temperature increased the particle size of the HAP catalyst and decreased the HAP surface area [30,31]. Evidently, the S BET values of HAP-200-24 samples decreased from 44 to 20 m2 g−1 with increasing the calcination temperature from 300 and 600 °C, confirming the decrement of surface area due to high-temperature calcination. Therefore, the calcination temperature affected the catalytic activity of the HAP catalyst by influencing its specific surface area. Fig. S5 further signifies the correlation between the S BET of HAP-200-24 catalyst with its activity. 3.4 Effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of the HAP catalyst Fig. 4 displays the effect of reaction temperature on the HD conversion over HAP-200-24 catalyst. The HD conversion decreased with the course of TOS at any reaction temperatures. The initial HD conversion increased with the increment of reaction temperature. The MCP selectivity of the HAP-200-24 catalyst was relatively stable at reaction temperatures of 300 and 350 ºC (>90%). The reaction temperature of 250 ºC had the highest selectivity towards MCP (>95%) for the first three hours, which then dropped to 69% afterwards. At a high temperature of 400 °C, the HAP-200-24 catalyst seemed to be stable, but the conversion decreased after TOS of 3 h and the MCP selectivity was less than 90%. Furthermore, the color of the reaction mixture at this high reaction temperature of 400 °C was black, and the unidentified by-products contained tar-like polymeric species. 3.5 Poisoning effect using ammonia and CO2 gases The acid-base pair site plays an essential role during catalytic aldol condensation [13,32]. The acid-base properties of the HAP catalyst were investigated by NH3- and CO2-TPD, while the role of the acid-base site during aldol condensation was analyzed by poisoning experiment with CO2 and NH3 gas. Fig. 5 reveals the acid-base properties of some HAP catalysts. The NH3 desorbed from the HAP catalysts (Fig. 5A) appeared in the temperature range from 100° to 300°C, indicating the presence of weak acid sites [15,33,34]. Fig. 5A also shows that the aging at 80 °C increased the acid concentration of the HAP catalyst, as seen by the higher NH3 uptake of the HAP-80-24 than that of the HAP-25-0. The low acid amount in the HAP-200-24 catalyst was probably due to the significant decrement in the specific surface area, as shown in Table 1 (Entry 6). Fig. 5B shows that the concentration of the base site in the HAP catalyst increased as the aging temperature increased. The concentration of base sites of the HAP-25-0 was the lowest compared to the HAP-80-24 and HAP-200-24 catalysts. The CO2 desorption of the HAP-80-24 and HAP-200-24 catalysts were rather similar, suggesting similar basic properties of these two catalysts. It is worth noting that the HAP-80-24 and HAP-200-24 catalysts had asymmetric CO2 desorption peaks maxima around 200 °C with a shoulder at a temperature above 300 °C, which suggested the transition of weak to medium base strength. Conversely, the CO2 desorption peak of the HAP-25-0 catalyst was located at a lower temperature, indicating the existence of a relatively weaker base site. Fig. 5 also displays that the silica-contaminated HAP, SiO2-HAP-200-24, possessed a smaller concentration of acid and base sites. This finding suggests that the silica contamination reduces the acid and base amount which consecutively decreases the catalytic activity of the SiO2-HAP-200-24 catalyst (Table 1, entry 7). However, we cannot explain the increment of the selectivity to a by-product, DMF, by the reduction of acid sites. Previous reports have suggested that the OH- site is responsible for the basic properties of the HAP [35,36]. Fig. 2 indicated that the HAP-25-0 contained a significant amount of carbonate and nitrate species, and the aging at temperatures above 50 °C for 24 h effectively removed this residual carbonate and nitrate (Fig. S2). The residual carbonate and nitrate species could reduce the basicity of HAP by replacing the OH- groups in the HAP catalyst. On the other hand, the aging temperature of 80 °C effectively removed the carbonate species leaving only a small amount of residual nitrate in the HAP-80-24 catalyst (Figs. 2B and S2). As a result, this small amount of residual nitrate did not significantly reduce the basicity of the HAP-80-24 catalyst. Meanwhile, the surface area of the HAP-200-24 was smaller than that of the HAP-80-24 (Table 1, Entries 3 and 6). Consequently, the base site concentration of the HAP-200-24 was smaller than that of the HAP-80-24 catalyst despite having neither residual carbonate nor nitrate, as depicted in Fig. 2C. These findings also demonstrate that the aging could effectively increase the strength and concentration of the base site in the HAP catalyst by removing the residual carbonate and nitrate species (Fig. 5B). The poisoning effect of CO2 and NH3 gas on the catalytic activity of the HAP-200-24 catalyst at 300 °C was illustrated in Fig. S7. The catalytic activity of the HAP-200-24 catalyst during the aldol condensation in N2 with 5% NH3 and 5% CO2 gas was smaller than that in pure N2 gas. In the poisoning experiment, the average HD conversion at TOS of 1–5 h were 22.5%, 14.5%, and 8.9% in N2, 5% NH3, and 5% CO2, respectively. The large decrement of HD conversion in 5% CO2 indicates that base sites acted as the active sites. Previously, we have found that the CO2 and NH3 could be adsorbed on the acid and base sites of the catalyst during dehydration of butanediols and acted as a catalyst poison that suppressed the catalytic activity during the dehydration [22,23]. Jiang et al. have reported that the aldehyde or ketone was adsorbed on the acid site of the catalyst, while the base site was responsible for abstracting the proton during aldol condensation [37]. It is reasonable that the NH3 decreased the catalytic activity of the HAP catalyst by blocking the adsorption site of HD, while the CO2 impeded the aldol condensation by blocking the base site for the proton abstraction. The catalytic activity of the HAP-200-24 catalyst in 5% CO2 flow was lower than that in the 5% NH3 flow, indicating that the CO2 gas poisoned the HAP catalyst severely. The CO2-TPD curves in Fig. 5B and some reports [35,38,39] have suggested that CO2 gas could be adsorbed strongly on the base site of the HAP catalyst and formed carbonate species by reacting with the OH- site. Meanwhile, weak interaction between NH3 gas and acid site of HAP catalyst occurred, as confirmed by NH3-TPD, causing lesser hindrance for the adsorption of HD on HAP surface. This finding also confirms that the intramolecular aldol condensation of HD to MCP proceeded over the acid-base concerted site of the HAP catalyst. According to the above discussion, we speculate a probable reaction mechanism for the aldol condensation of HD as well as a side reaction of dehydrocyclization to DMF, as shown in Fig. 6. It is reasonable that the OH group of HAP causes the base sites for the aldol condensation and calcium cations act as the Lewis acid for the adsorption sites of HD. Fig. 6A illustrates a probable mechanism for the HD-to-MCP aldol condensation: at first, HD is adsorbed on the acidic Ca2+ cation with the oxygen of a carbonyl group [40–42]; a basic OH- group of HAP abstracts the terminal hydrogen of HD to produce an enolate anion [42,43]; The enolate anion attacks the neighboring carbonyl group to be cyclized; finally, dehydration of the cyclic aldol to produce MCP and water. On the other hand, the DMF formation would proceed over weaker basic and rather acidic surface sites than the favorable sites for the MCP formation. The contaminant carbonate ion could reduce the basicity of HAP by replacing the OH group that is efficient for the aldol condensation. Fig. 6B also shows a possible mechanism for the DMF formation: an HD anchored to a Lewis acid site, Ca2+, of HAP through a carbonyl group and another carbonyl group could attack a proton with a form of bicarbonate, HCO3 -, in HAP catalyst to form a carbocation; lone-pair electrons of carbonyl oxygen attack the carbocation to form 3-hydro-4-hydroxy-2,5-dimethylfuran, which could be readily dehydrated to produce DMF. 3.6 Deactivation control by Ag-H2 method As shown in Figs. 4, S1, S3, and S4, the HD conversion gradually decreased with the course of TOS in all the catalysts. Even in the liquid-phase aldol condensation of HD at 140 °C, a similar deactivation was observed over alumina catalysts [9]. Our previous works have shown that the utilization of Ag-modified catalyst and H2 as a carrier gas could improve the stability of the catalytic activity for various vapor-phase reactions [13,34,44,45]. The same strategy was employed to control catalyst deactivation during aldol condensation reaction over the HAP-200-24 catalyst. Fig. 7 shows that the Ag-modified HAP-200-24 catalyst in H2 flow had superior stability compared to the unmodified-HAP catalyst. Notably, the initial HD conversion was improved significantly by the Ag-H2 modification at all reaction temperatures assessed. Severe catalyst deactivation was still observed at the reaction temperature of 250 °C even in H2 over Ag-HAP (Fig. 7B). However, a substantial improvement in the catalyst stability was observed at the reaction temperature of 300 °C and 325 °C using the 5Ag-HAP-200-24 catalyst under the flow of H2 gas. Contrary, in N2 carrier gas, the HAP catalyst underwent rapid deactivation due to coke formation at reaction temperatures of 300 and 325 °C (Fig. 7A). These results suggest that the modification of the HAP catalyst by Ag and the operation in H2 gas effectively stabilize the HAP catalyst during intramolecular aldol condensation. It is worth noting that the MCP selectivity was not significantly affected by the modification of Ag and operation in H2 gas (Fig. S8). The importance of H2 gas and Ag in improving the catalytic stability of the HAP catalyst was investigated by changing the reaction conditions, and the results are summarized in Fig. 8. Without Ag modification, the HAP catalyst deactivated even when H2 gas was employed as a carrier gas (Fig. 8A). This finding signifies the importance of Ag for controlling catalyst deactivation. However, the Ag-HAP catalyst could not maintain its stability in the absence of H2 gas (Fig. 8B). Fig. 8B (open circle) shows that the Ag-HAP catalyst was still deactivated when the carrier gas was N2 instead of H2 gas. From these findings, it can be said that both Ag and H2 gas played an essential role in stabilizing the catalyst during aldol condensation. Fig. S9 shows that different reaction conditions did not alter the high MCP selectivity. Despite the clear decrement of the HD conversion with TOS for the unmodified HAP-200-24 catalyst, these findings are not sufficient to explain the catalyst deactivation. Previous reports have shown a quantitative analysis to elaborate the catalyst deactivation during vapor-phase reactions [46–48]. Referring to these works, we calculated the quantitative analysis for catalyst deactivation and found out that the HAP catalyst was indeed rapidly deactivated without modification with Ag and H2 gas (Fig. S10). On the other hand, the catalyst deactivation was significantly reduced by modification with Ag and operation in H2 gas (Figs. S11 and S12). We have previously reported that the role of Ag and H2 in stabilizing the catalyst was related to inhibiting the coke deposition on the TiO2 catalyst used in the aldol condensation of butanal [13]. The Ag could adsorb and dissociate H2 to form H-species, which are later transferred onto the catalyst surface by the spillover effect [49–51]. The adsorbed H-species inhibited the formation of carbonaceous species by preventing dehydrogenation reaction, which was generally the main route for the carbonaceous formation [45]. This assumption was confirmed by the TG analysis shown in Fig. 9. The weight loss in the TG curve was attributed to the coke deposition on the catalyst during the aldol condensation of HD. The coke accumulated in the Ag-HAP catalyst, as depicted by the weight loss, was significantly smaller than that on the HAP catalyst. Therefore, it can be said that modification of the HAP catalyst with the Ag-H2 method successfully diminished the coke formation, which improved the HAP stability during HD aldol condensation. 4 Conclusion The selective vapor-phase intramolecular condensation of HD to MCP successfully proceeded over a non-precious HAP catalyst prepared by the aging of the as-prepared apatite precipitate. The aging temperature and aging time affected the residual carbonate and nitrate species and the specific surface area of the resulting HAP catalyst, which consecutively affected its catalytic performance. This residual carbonate species majorly decreased the specific surface area and the MCP selectivity by catalyzing the DMF formation. The HAP catalysts aged at a temperature between 50 and 200 ºC showed the highest HD conversion with a high MCP selectivity of ca. 95%. The intramolecular aldol condensation over the HAP catalyst proceeded over the acid-base concerted site, as confirmed by the poisoning experiment using NH3 and CO2 gas. Severe deactivation of the HAP catalysts was observed in an N2 flow due to coke formation. The catalyst modification with Ag and the operation in H2 flow effectively improved the stability of the HAP catalyst by inhibiting the coke formation, allowing the HAP catalyst to maintain its high selectivity (ca. 95%) at high HD conversion. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase production of 3-methylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (MCP) via intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione (HD) was performed over calcium hydroxyapatite (HAP) catalysts aged under various conditions. The aging temperature and time of the as-prepared apatite precipitate significantly affected the catalytic activity of the resulting HAP catalyst by influencing its residual carbonate and nitrate species and specific surface area. The HAP aged at a temperature between 50 and 200 ºC showed the highest catalytic activity with a high MCP selectivity of ca. 95%. However, serious deactivation was observed in an N2 carrier gas flow due to coke formation. The modification of the HAP catalyst with silver and the utilization of H2 as a carrier gas significantly reduced the coke formation and improved the catalytic stability during aldol condensation of HD to MCP.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor-phase intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione over calcium hydroxyapatite catalyst
